summary:
When developing a new treatment, we always talk ABOUT patients. But we should be talking TO them more often, en really LISTEN, to understand what would bring value to their lives and how a new treatment could address their unmet needs.

In my current role as Health Value Translation Lead at Sanofi, I am responsible to ensure the Patient Voice is taken into account throughout development of a new asset. As part of the Patient Informed Development & Health Value Translation team, I work closely together with Patient Engagement Leads and Clinical Outcome Assessment scientist, to bring the patient-informed science to the global project teams. My focus is in the oncology area, working on both hematological and well as solid organ malignancies. The aim is to differentiate our products from current and future treatments to help build the value dossier from a patient perspective. This requires a thorough understanding of patient needs and preferences and in-depth evaluation of patient’s perception of the new treatment. Furthermore, we deep-dive into the heterogeneity of the target patient population to help inform the Diversity & Inclusion strategy for clinical trials. 

I studied pharmacy at the University of Ghent, Belgium, followed by a PhD in Advanced Drug Delivery at the University of Utrecht, The Netherlands. As Head of PMO at Kiadis Pharma I was responsible to set-up a project-centric way of working and establish effective governance and decision-making processes. Upon the acquisition by Sanofi, I had the opportunity to help manage the integration of people, projects and processes. Before joining Kiadis/Sanofi, I was part of the Corporate Scientific Department of Nordic Pharma, responsible for Product Development and Project Management. I started my career in the industry as a Scientist in Early Pharmaceutical Development.

My background in pharmacy and the roles I had till date allow me to both dive into the science when needed, as well as to oversee the full development trajectory of any type of drug product.

Dynamic, confident and passionate is how I would describe my personality. I enjoy working at a strategic level, in a multi-disciplinary and international environment. My strong points are my natural leadership and my ability to zoom out and present complex matter at a high level. In my job, I thrive when I feel that I am making the difference, when my actions have impact. I am mostly appreciated for my enthusiasm, open and result-driven attitude, excellent communication skills, eagerness to learn and my personal drive.

profile_positions.description:
As Director R&D I took part in the management team of Disphar in the Netherlands, but also reports to the CEO of the Nordic Group in Paris. I was responsible for the progress of the R&D portfolio for both Disphar and Nordic. In this role I managed a team of 4 Project Managers and 1 Patent Attorney. All projects handled by the team concerned the development of new products of  known chemical compounds, from feasibility through pharmaceutical and clinical development, to registration of the file. The development work was outsourced to external CMOs or to sister companies in Mumbai (India) and Malmö (Sweden).
The daily challenges of my team were the dual role (being both project manager and scientist), the art of outsourcing and dealing with cultural differences. What motivated me most in this role is the growth of the team, in terms of knowledge and skills, making sure everyone is enthusiastic about their projects.
profile_positions.title: Director R&D

profile_positions.description: As a Team Leader R&D, I broadened my responsibilities from project to people management. I combined management of my own projects with leading a small team of Project Managers. I was also responsible for operational improvement within the R&D team. Given the nature of the projects I was involved in, as well as due to the set-up of the company structure, I was very much involved in the actual scientific (i.e. pharmaceutical development) content of some projects. I truly enjoyed this combination of science and management and found pleasure in leading, coaching, presenting, and working in international teams.
profile_positions.title: Team Leader R&D

profile_positions.description:
In October 2010 I started my career as Project Manager, being responsible for managing multiple projects simultaneously. All projects concerned the development of generic drugs, from feasibility through pharmaceutical and clinical development, to registration of the file. All development activities were outsourced to contract partners around the globe.  Apart from the regulatory and quality team members, all located in the Netherlands, the project teams led by me consisted of technical experts at the contract labs. For a large number of projects the pharmaceutical development was performed at Indeus, a sister-company of Disphar, located in Mumbai. I frequently traveled to Mumbai for more in-dept discussions on the projects. I regarded working with third parties, in international teams, in which cultural differences can be immense, as the most challenging and rewarding part of the job. 
In addition to the content discussions and overall management of the projects, I enjoyed presenting to higher management. Moreover, in view of the implementation of QbD at both Indeus and Disphar, I gave a number of internal trainings on this subject, allowing to further develop my presentation skills.
profile_positions.title: R&D Project Manager

profile_positions.description:
As a Scientist in Early Pharmaceutical Development, I was responsible for the development of formulations of New Chemical Entities, from pre-clinical up to phase I clinical studies. Every NCE generates new challenges and requires a suitable development approach to be puzzled out. The activities of a Pharmaceutical Scientist therefore included the setup of a strategy, practical development of formulations and writing of protocols, reports and source documents for regulatory purposes.  Successful development of an NCE is strongly dependent on close collaboration between all disciplines involved, i.e. pharmacy, chemistry, analytics, toxicology, clinical pharmacology, etc. Regularly, I was involved in interdisciplinary meetings to update the team on the progress of the project. I consulted experts on a day-to-day basis, both within the company as outside, e.g. in the academic world. 
Within the pharmaceutical platform, I was contact person for internships and organized so-called ‘nose around’ internships during which students could get acquainted with different roles pharmacists can play in the development of a new drug, from discovery up to market launch.
profile_positions.title: Scientist in Early Pharmaceutical Development
